title: If Lisp is So Great
title_zh: [待翻译] If Lisp is So Great

paragraphs: May 2003If Lisp is so great, why don't more people use it? I was asked this question by a student in the audience at a talk I gave recently. Not for the first time, either.In languages, as in so many things, there's not much correlation between popularity and quality.

Why does John Grisham (King of Torts sales rank, 44) outsell Jane Austen (Pride and Prejudice sales rank, 6191)? Would even Grisham claim that it's because he's a better writer?Here's the first sentence of Pride and Prejudice: It is a truth universally acknowledged, that a single man in possession of a good fortune must be in want of a wife.

"It is a truth universally acknowledged?" Long words for the first sentence of a love story.Like Jane Austen, Lisp looks hard. Its syntax, or lack of syntax, makes it look completely unlike the languages most people are used to.

Before I learned Lisp, I was afraid of it too. I recently came across a notebook from 1983 in which I'd written: I suppose I should learn Lisp, but it seems so foreign. Fortunately, I was 19 at the time and not too resistant to learning new things.

I was so ignorant that learning almost anything meant learning new things.People frightened by Lisp make up other reasons for not using it. The standard excuse, back when C was the default language, was that Lisp was too slow.

Now that Lisp dialects are among the faster languages available, that excuse has gone away. Now the standard excuse is openly circular: that other languages are more popular.(Beware of such reasoning.

It gets you Windows.)Popularity is always self-perpetuating, but it's especially so in programming languages. More libraries get written for popular languages, which makes them still more popular. Programs often have to work with existing programs, and this is easier if they're written in the same language, so languages spread from program to program like a virus.

And managers prefer popular languages, because they give them more leverage over developers, who can more easily be replaced.Indeed, if programming languages were all more or less equivalent, there would be little justification for using any but the most popular.

But they aren't all equivalent, not by a long shot. And that's why less popular languages, like Jane Austen's novels, continue to survive at all. When everyone else is reading the latest John Grisham novel, there will always be a few people reading Jane Austen instead.Japanese TranslationRomanian TranslationSpanish Translation

在语言方面，就像在许多其他事情上一样，流行程度和质量之间并没有太大的关联。

paragraphs.original: Why does John Grisham (King of Torts sales rank, 44) outsell Jane Austen (Pride and Prejudice sales rank, 6191)? Would even Grisham claim that it's because he's a better writer?Here's the first sentence of Pride and Prejudice: It is a truth universally acknowledged, that a single man in possession of a good fortune must be in want of a wife.
paragraphs.translated: 为什么约翰·格里森（侵权法之王，销量排名44）的书比简·奥斯汀（《傲慢与偏见》，销量排名6191）的书卖得好？格里森会声称这是因为他的文笔更好吗？以下是《傲慢与偏见》的第一句话：凡是有钱的单身汉，总想娶位太太，这已经成了一条举世公认的真理。

paragraphs.original: "It is a truth universally acknowledged?" Long words for the first sentence of a love story.Like Jane Austen, Lisp looks hard. Its syntax, or lack of syntax, makes it look completely unlike the languages most people are used to.
paragraphs.translated: “这是普遍公认的真理？” 这句话作为爱情故事的开篇显得有些冗长。像简·奥斯汀的作品一样，Lisp 看起来令人费解。它的语法，或者说是缺乏语法，使得它与大多数人习惯的编程语言完全不同。

paragraphs.original: Before I learned Lisp, I was afraid of it too. I recently came across a notebook from 1983 in which I'd written: I suppose I should learn Lisp, but it seems so foreign. Fortunately, I was 19 at the time and not too resistant to learning new things.
paragraphs.translated: 在学习Lisp之前，我也害怕过。最近我翻到了1983年的一本笔记本，里面写着：我想我应该学Lisp，但它看起来太陌生了。幸运的是，当时我19岁，对学习新事物还不太抵触。

paragraphs.original: I was so ignorant that learning almost anything meant learning new things.People frightened by Lisp make up other reasons for not using it. The standard excuse, back when C was the default language, was that Lisp was too slow.
paragraphs.translated: 我如此无知，以至于学习几乎任何东西都意味着学到新知识。那些被Lisp吓到的人会编造其他不使用它的理由。在C语言是默认选择的年代，标准的借口是Lisp太慢。

paragraphs.original: Now that Lisp dialects are among the faster languages available, that excuse has gone away. Now the standard excuse is openly circular: that other languages are more popular.(Beware of such reasoning.
paragraphs.translated: 现在 Lisp 方言已经是可用的较快的语言之一，这个借口已经不成立了。现在常用的借口变得 openly circular：其他语言更流行。（当心这种逻辑。）

paragraphs.original: It gets you Windows.)Popularity is always self-perpetuating, but it's especially so in programming languages. More libraries get written for popular languages, which makes them still more popular. Programs often have to work with existing programs, and this is easier if they're written in the same language, so languages spread from program to program like a virus.
paragraphs.translated: 它让你用上 Windows。）流行总是自我延续的，但在编程语言中尤为如此。为流行语言编写的库更多，这使得它们更加流行。程序经常需要与现有程序协同工作，如果它们是用同一种语言编写的，这会更容易，因此语言像病毒一样从一个程序传播到另一个程序。

paragraphs.original: And managers prefer popular languages, because they give them more leverage over developers, who can more easily be replaced.Indeed, if programming languages were all more or less equivalent, there would be little justification for using any but the most popular.
paragraphs.translated: 经理们更喜欢流行的语言，因为这让他们对开发人员有更大的控制力，开发人员也更容易被替换。事实上，如果编程语言在功能上都差不多，那么使用最流行的语言之外的任何语言都没有什么合理的理由。

paragraphs.original: But they aren't all equivalent, not by a long shot. And that's why less popular languages, like Jane Austen's novels, continue to survive at all. When everyone else is reading the latest John Grisham novel, there will always be a few people reading Jane Austen instead.Japanese TranslationRomanian TranslationSpanish Translation
paragraphs.translated: 但它们绝不是等同的。这也就是为什么像简·奥斯汀的小说这样的不太流行的语言能够继续生存下去。当其他人都在阅读最新的约翰·格里沙姆小说时，总会有少数人选择阅读简·奥斯汀的作品。日语翻译罗马尼亚语翻译西班牙语翻译
